BE

Our view: Glencore's production numbers today were slightly below/inline with our estimates, however, this production report was always prone to some small
variance being the first full quarter following the production scale back in Q4. Full year production guidance has been reiterated across the board (except for a
small 0.3kbbl downgrade in oil) and Marketing EBIT is still expected in the $2.4-$2.7bn range for FY 2016 (RBC $2.5bn). The decision to defer the restart of the
second line at Koniambo is a small positive for the nickel market (although expectations likely heavily discounted on near-term production ramp already).
Perhaps more importantly, last night the FT reported that Glencore has engaged advisors to sell its Vasilovskoye Gold mine in Kazakhstan, part of the Kazzinc
portfolio. Vasilovskoye (70% owned) is a 2g/t open pit operation with 10+ years of reserve life. There is limited data available on the mine, but the recent
depreciation of the Kazakh Tenge (having depreciated from 180 to 330/USD) should have substantially augmented cash flow. A heavily caveated, back-of-theenvelope
NAV (assuming a $700/oz AISC at $1,300/oz gold) provides ~$1.1-$1.3bn. Assuming a gold multiple P/NPV of 1.5-1.7x (with takeover premium) would
generate a 100% equity - $1.7bn to $2.2bn range, not dissimilar to the $2bn value quoted in the FT. We carry the cashflow from gold as a whole in Kazzinc at
1 . 0 x N A V , w h i c h i m p l i e s t h e s a l e s h o u l d p r o v i d e a N A V p o s i t i v e e v e n t , b u t m o r e i m p o r t a n t l y t h i s w i l l a l s o h e l p t o a c c e l e r a t e t h e
deleveraging program even more following the recent $2.5bn sale of the Ag business.
Glencore Q1 production of copper was 335kt vs. RBC 344kt, zinc at 257.1kt vs. RBC 271kt, nickel at 27.6kt vs. RBC at 28.1kt and coal at 29.7kt vs. RBC at 31.7kt.

BE

Sorry about the formatting in the middle. Not sure why that happened.

BE

And Canaccord.

11:19 am
BE

Glencore 1Q16 production report slightly better than forecast
Glencore reported a mixed but slightly better set of production numbers for the opening
quarter of 2016. Base metals production on average was 4% better than we anticipated,
with Energy a touch below our forecasts and Ags beating our numbers.
Metals & Mining: Copper and Nickel strong, Zinc curtailed
Glencore’s 1Q16 base metals production came in 4% better than our forecast with Zinc
the only major metal to miss our forecasts. Copper production came in at 335,000t vs
CG at 325,000t, driven by a better quarterly performance at Antamina (higher grades,
recoveries as well as material mined and milled already reported by BHP). Nickel
production came in at 27,600kt (CG at 25,000t) with production at INO up 16% yoy and
2-3,000t ahead of our forecasts for the quarter. Meanwhile, zinc production of 257,000t
missed our 1Q16 forecast (CG at 275,000t) with production down across the board due
to the ongoing production curtailments in the division, as well as a sequentially weaker
quarter at Kazzinc.
Energy: Coal lower on Optimum
Coal production came in at 29.7Mt vs CG at 31.5Mt due to the full deconsolidation of
Optimum which closed earlier this year. Average AP14 and Newcastle coal prices came in
at US$51-52/t in 1Q16 (CG using US$51/t realised). Oil on an entitled basis came in at
2.4MM bbl, a bit better than our forecast of 2.3MM bbl.
Guidance tweaked down for Oil
Production guidance for Metals and Mining and Coal remains unchanged for the year.
However, Glencore has modestly revised down its Oil production guidance to 8.2MM
bbl on an entitled basis (previously 8.5MM bbl). Marketing EBIT guidance remains
unchanged at US$2.4-2.7bn for 2016.
Potential Kazakh gold mine sale
Today's Financial Times says that Glencore's 70%-owned Kazzinc subsidiary is
considering options on its 350,000ozpa Vasilkovskoye gold mine in Kazakhstan, that
includes a sale, potentially to Chinese interests, or a streaming deal. The article places a
price tag of US$2bn on the mine, which sounds high to us, though we have little detail on
the operation.
Travails of agricultural commodity traders
Today's Financial Times also carries an article highlighting the challenges facing
agricultural commodity traders. Each leading trading company has a differing portfolio of
businesses, so it's hard to directly read across for Glencore, but Archer Daniels Midland
(ADM : NYSE : US$39.1 | NR), one of Glencore's US competitors, yesterday reported Q1
earnings of US$230M, off 53% on Q1 2015.

The Federal Public Prosecution Service has announced that it has commenced proceedings against Samarco Mineração S.A (Samarco), Vale and BHP Billiton Brasil LTDA (BHP Billiton Brasil) for BRL 155 billion (approximately US$43 billion at current exchange rates) for social, environmental and economic compensation in relation to the failure of the Fundão tailings dam at the Samarco iron ore operation in Minas Gerais, Brazil on 5 November 2015.

Soem snap Shore

11:23 am
PM

Brazilian prosecutors seeking c.US$43bn for Samarco disaster; we believe much-lower settlement likely, but expect shares to dive today.. Ouch. Brazil’s Federal Public Prosecution Service is apparently seeking BRL155bn (c.US$43bn) from Samarco, Vale and BHP in relation to the November 2015 tailings dam disaster (BHP has not yet received formal notice of the claim).

This civil action is separate from the settlement agreed with the Brazilian government in March 2016, wherein the companies agreed to pay c.BRL20bn over many years. Federal and state prosecutors were not part of that settlement, and the former criticised the settlement as being insufficient and lacking in legal enforceability.

The good news, according to Bloomberg, is that Brazilian prosecutors have a history of demanding large reparations for environmental disasters, which are subsequently settled at much lower amounts. Nonetheless, we expect a red day for the shares today.

Anyway, key numbers via Barclays.

BE

Key numbers:

· Retail EBIT: £635mn (vs Barclays £635mn) ; Sainsbury’s Bank EBIT £65m (vs Barclays £65m)

· Group underlying EBIT of £700m (vs Barclays £700m, BBG consensus of £683m)

· Underlying PBT of £587m – a decline of 13.8% (vs Barclays at £586m and company-collated consensus of £573m). The 2H decline in PBT was -8.8%.

· The FY dividend of 12.1p was ahead of the company-collated consensus of 11.1p (Barclays at 11.8p) – this was driven by the beat further up the P&L given the defined 50% payout ratio.

· Net debt (if treating perpetual securities as debt) stood at £2,320mn at the end of FY15/16, a touch lower than the £2.34bn at end 14/15 but a little higher than our forecast of £2.26bn.

First impressions:

· FY underlying Retail EBIT margin was 2.74%, a decline of 33bps (or -39bps excluding fuel) – this implies a slightly slower decline in 2H than in 1H (when the exc-fuel margin fell by 45bps).

· Sainsbury states that it is on course to deliver its target of £500m cost savings by the end of 2017/18, having delivered £225m in 2015/16.

· Overall this set of results look broadly as expected with no obvious issues. On first reading there is no new detail on the Home Retail acquisition and nothing very specific on outlook.

Valuation

Sainsbury trades on a 2017E PE of 11.9x versus the European sector on 13.2x and closest peers Tesco on 18.8x and Morrison on 16.2x.

11:30 am
BE

And comment on them from SocGen.

BE

This is an encouraging publication but the short-term key issue is management’s outlook for 2016-17. We may have more flavour after this morning’s analyst meeting at 9.30 UK time. Regarding the proposed acquisition of Home Retail Group, management indicated that the deal could take place in the third quarter of the calendar year, at which point it will give further guidance on how the group will account for and report on the acquisition. Our 260p TP is based on a peer comparison (255p, a 35% 2016-17e P/E discount to the European food retailing sector) and a DCF (265p, WACC 8.6%, growth to perpetuity 1.5%, normalised EBIT margin 3.0% as of 2022-23e). The risks to our price target, rating and recommendation: on the downside, higher price investment (£150m planned for 2015-16) and higher one-off costs related to HRG bid (£130m targeted by management); on the upside, higher HRG synergies than the ‘at least £160m’ targeted by the group.

BE

And Caz, perma-bear on Sainsbury.

11:31 am
BE

 Guidance. Limited guidance has been provided for 2016/17. This is
understandable as it is in the context of Sainsbury’s offer for HR. Few
guidance snippets as follows: 1) Sainsbury expects to remain competitive on
price in the market, with food price deflation likely to continue in the
second half of 2016/17; 2) cost inflation is expected at the lower end of the
2-3% range; 3) operational cost savings are expected to be around £120
million (15/16 £225mn); 4) net debt expected to reduce YoY; 5) capex
guided at around £550mn, in line with ty and depreciation expense; 6)
expects Bank operating profit to be c10% lower YoY, due to investment
required to enter the mortgage market and the impact of reduced
interchange fees. We note that no guidance has been provided for LFLs in
the year. We believe that the outcome of the combination of ongoing topline
deflation and cost inflation, combined with lower cost savings going
forward, is likely going to be one of margins contracting further.

 Big 4 all reporting deteriorating sales trend: In order of deterioration, J
Sainsbury (SBRY LN, £2.86, Neutral, TP: £2.90), ASDA (NR), Tesco (TSCO
LN, £1.69, Outperform, TP: £2.50), Wm Morrison Supermarkets (MRW LN,
£1.91, Neutral, TP: £1.90) all reported falling run rate delta in growth rate. This
was exacerbated by differing comparison bases, but the order is still the same.
 ASDA pricing gap perhaps slightly overstated recently: As we note in Fig
13, Grocer 33 data shows ASDA improving pricing meaningfully in last few
weeks. We believe this to have been driven by some exceptional data points
(and some large value items working in its favour) which may begin to decline.
 ALDI/LIDL: While LIDL growth rate fell back to low DD, it and Iceland were
the only banners to see improving adjusted growth rates. ALDI’s improving
trend on the other hand is a function of comparison base.
 Deflation: UK food price deflation stayed at -1.5% in 12 weeks to 24 April.
With SBRY and MRW launching new price cuts this week, there is a risk that
this starts to fall again.

BE

Tesco's pricing more or less stable vs. Sainsbury & Morrison... Our
sample basket of national brands comparable across the Big 3 was 3.8%
cheaper (incl. promotions) at Tesco than at Sainsbury. This is slightly worse
than in March (it was 4.2% cheaper then), but compares to 1.8% cheaper on
average since July 2011 (see Exhibit1). As for the 3-month averaged data
(Exhibit 2), it continues to show encouraging trends for Tesco's pricing relative
to Sainsbury's. Interestingly, Tesco's relative prices look less appealing when
considering the more restricted basket common to the Big 4 (i.e. including
Morrison, added to our price survey in March 2014), suggesting perhaps that
price competition year to date is focused on the core assortment: both
Sainsbury and Morrison are just under 1% cheaper than Tesco on this core
assortment (more or less stable vs. March).

11:37 am
BE

… but losing to Asda, which seems to have become more aggressive on
price lately. In our March survey, we saw the first signs that Asda could be
moving on pricing, with a notable improvement in its relative prices on the
core ~300 branded SKUs stocked across the Big 4 (see Exhibit 4). The April
survey shows an improvement in Asda's pricing on the 400+ assortment
stocked at the Big 3, as well as the core ~300 branded SKUs. Indeed, our
sample Asda basket was 4.5% cheaper than Tesco's this month, the largest gap
since September 2015. On the narrower Big 4 basket, Asda's price gap to
Tesco has remained more or less stable, suggesting Asda's price gap to Tesco
is now back to the typical levels seen in 2014. We continue to see Asda as the
industry's main wild card this year: in a bear case scenario where Asda decides
to reset its margin, it could lead to a halving of the industry's profit pool

BE

You'll have to speak to them yourself for exhibits 2, 3 and 4.

11:38 am
BE

Oh! Actually! One more thing on grocers.

BE

Bernstein downgrade of Morrison.

BE

MRW is up 38% since Dec., best performance of our coverage. Amazon-deal excitement or trading hopes have run well ahead of reality. Structural challenges MRW haven't gone away (weak differentiation, weak growth) and Tesco just landed Farm Brands.
Even with the most rose-tinted glasses on Amazon deal and higher than guidance medium term PBT improvements, we are still 10% below EPS this year. Even if we were to use consensus EPS and EPS growth, it still looks 20% overvalued.
At today's share price, MRW trades at lower FCF yield than Ahold, even 2yrs out with more MRW recovery built in. Hence our downgrade to Underperform with a PT of £1.60. Beware short term catalyst of Q1 sales, it may be good but doesn't change fundamentals

BE

BE

11:53 am
BE

11:55 am
BE

Morgan Stanley can summarise where we are.

BE

Net income came in at $1.6bn, ahead of consensus of $1.0bn.
Downstream was once again stronger than expected, offset by a
weaker Upstream result. Production surprised positively, but net
debt also came in several billion higher than expected. More to come
at the strategy presentation on 7 June.

BE

Upstream + Integrated Gas (lower vs consensus): Upstream and
Integrated Gas reported combined after-tax net operating income of
$(443)m, slightly below consensus of $(210). A profit in Integrated Gas of
$994m was offset by a sizeable loss in Upstream of $(1.4)bn.
Downstream (higher vs consensus): After-tax net operating earnings of
$2.0bn were ahead of consensus of $1.7bn. Across the downstream,
industry margins came under pressure, leading to a y/y fall in Chemicals
earnings. Yet, Oil Products held up better than expected.

11:55 am
BE

Production stronger than expected: Shell consolidated production from BG
for part of the quarter. As a result, production increased to 3,661 kboe/d,
substantially above our forecast of 3,521 kboe/d. BG's assets produced 796
kb/d in the quarter, up another 5% compared to 4Q.
Organic FCF remains weak, as expected: Operating cash flow came in at
$4.9bn (excluding changes in working capital), and organic capex fell to $5.7bn
(down 15% vs 1Q16, the lowest level since 2Q 2011), leaving organic FCF of
$(0.8)bn. The quarterly dividend runs at ~$3.8bn, hence leaving a sizeable gap,
reflecting depressed oil prices during the quarter.
Net debt higher than expected: Shell reported net debt of ~$69bn, which
was substantially higher than our estimate of just below $60bn. Approximately
$5bn seems to be related to the capitalisation of a number of finance leases,
which we had not reflected in our modeling. Still, the level of net debt leaves
some concern.
2016 Capital Investment lowered to $30bn vs. $33bn previously: Shell's
CEO highlighted that "capital investment in 2016 is clearly trending toward
$30bn, compared to previous guidance of $33bn". This also compares
favourably to MS estimate for capital investment of $31.5bn in 2016.
Cost savings coming through: Shell is guiding for operating costs to
continue to fall, reaching an annual run-rate of $40bn per year by the end of
the year, down from combined Shell+BG spend of $53bn in 2014.

BE

And SocGen.

BE

SG view Q1 cash from operations was weak at $661m, after a $3.9bn negative working
capital contribution, with $1.94bn of that being the payment to Iran. Underlying cash flow
of $4.6bn at $34/bbl, or c.$18-20bn annualised is well below the 10% lower capex
guidance of $30bn; with Exxon capex at $25bn, investors should anticipate further
reductions (Shell calls the process “dynamic” – meaning, it takes time). Divisionally, 48% of
Q1 cash flow was from Downstream, and 44% from Integrated Gas. We note an
acceleration in cost cutting, but no increase in overall BG synergies.
